title: Join the Lab
text:
We welcome motivated students and researchers who are excited about microbial ecology, evolution, and symbiosis, and who value a collaborative and inclusive environment.
Our research explores how microbial symbionts assemble, diversify, and function across environments, with a focus on the balance between determinism and contingency in community assembly and the role of mobile genetic elements in host–microbe interactions.



Population structure and genomic diversity of facultative symbionts

Interactions among mutualists, parasites, and hosts

Ecological and evolutionary rules of microbial community assembly

title: Laboratory for microbial symbiosis, ecology, and evolution
text:
Biology contains multitudes: ecological and evolutionary dynamics play out across multiple levels of organization — from host communities to symbiont consortia to mobile genetic elements.
Evolution is the study of history — how past mutations, rare events, and chance perturbations leave lasting imprints.
Ecology is the study of interdependence — how organisms interact with one another and their environments, shaping the diversity we see today.
Together, they frame a central question that drives our lab:
We aim to understand symbiosis in an ecological and evolutionary context across biological scales. We ask how deterministic forces (selection) and historical contingencies (mutations, rare events, environmental perturbations) interact to shape diversity.

title: Laboratory for microbial symbiosis, ecology, and evolution
text:
We are a new group at the Biodiversity Research Center, Academia Sinica in Taipei, Taiwan. The lab officially launches in November 2025, and we welcome applications at all levels. Join Us!
Our research sits at the interface of ecology, evolution, and systems biology. We study host-associated microbial communities— complex systems layered by hosts, symbionts, and mobile genes—with the goal of uncovering the simple rules that govern them. By integrating fieldwork, laboratory experiments, and theoretical models, we ask when and how diversity across multiple levels of organization emerges, persists, or collapses.

title: Laboratory for microbial symbiosis, ecology, and evolution
text:
What we study

Is biological diversity an inevitable outcome of deterministic selection, or the contingent result of historical chance?

Biology contains multitudes: ecological and evolutionary dynamics play out across multiple levels of organization — from host communities to symbiont consortia to mobile genetic elements.
Evolution is the study of history — how past mutations, rare events, and chance perturbations leave lasting imprints.
Ecology is the study of interdependence — how organisms interact with one another and their environments, shaping the diversity we see today.
Together, they frame a central question that drives our lab:
We aim to understand symbiosis in an ecological and evolutionary context across biological scales. We ask how deterministic forces (selection) and historical contingencies (mutations, rare events, environmental perturbations) interact to shape diversity.

title: Research
text:
What we’ve shown

Multispecies coexistence can be truly emergent. In synthetic communities, your work demonstrated that stable coexistence can arise even when pairs fail to coexist, underscoring that higher-order (3+ species) interactions are key to community stability. :contentReferenceoaicite:1
Directed evolution of communities works—if you manage heritability and variation. Across hundreds of evolving communities, selection improved function until between-community heritable variation was exhausted; theory then identified two design principles to keep improving: stabilize communities (raise heritability) and perturb ecologies (inject variation). :contentReferenceoaicite:2
Facultative symbionts diverge via interacting adaptive and non-adaptive processes. Using common-garden experiments and de novo genomes of Sinorhizobium, ongoing work reveals context-dependent divergence tied to host genotype, geography, and nutrients—illustrating how free-living and host-associated phases shape evolution. :contentReferenceoaicite:3

title: Research
text:
Study system & approach
We focus on legume–rhizobium nutrient mutualism (e.g., Medicago–Sinorhizobium) because it combines experimental tractability with natural relevance. Symbiosis genes are modular and often reside on mobile elements, enabling precise manipulation of efficiency and gene transfer. Methodologically, we integrate evolutionary genomics, modeling/machine learning, and high-throughput experimental evolution + phenotyping (automated liquid handling, computer-vision readouts, and cost-effective long-read sequencing). :contentReferenceoaicite:4 :contentReferenceoaicite:5

title: Research
text:
Where we’re going
Theme 1 — Ecological repeatability. How deterministic is host-driven community assembly? We measure repeatability of symbiont enrichment across replicate hosts and relate it to selection, host filtering, and microbe–microbe competition. :contentReferenceoaicite:6
Theme 2 — Genetic mechanisms (HGT). When, where, and how fast do symbiosis genes move, and do transfers drive gene-specific vs genome-wide sweeps? We engineer marked elements and manipulate donor/recipient backgrounds to quantify rates, directions, and ecological impacts of HGT. :contentReferenceoaicite:7 :contentReferenceoaicite:8
Theme 3 — Evolution across gradients. We map divergence of facultative symbionts along elevation and urbanization gradients and link fitness effects of gene gain/loss to environment and host context using high-throughput assays and genomics. :contentReferenceoaicite:9

title: Research
text:
Why this matters
Predictive ecology of symbiosis will help us design robust microbiomes, forecast stability under change, and improve crop yields via informed partner choice and gene flow management. It’s a synthesis of ecology (repeatability), evolution (divergence), and genetics (HGT), built on scalable experiments and computation. :contentReferenceoaicite:10

title: Laboratory for microbial symbiosis, ecology, and evolution
section: Theme I — Diversity at the level of host communities
text:
Theme I — Diversity at the level of host communities
Question: What drives the diversity in symbiosis at the level of host communities?
- Determinism (host selection): symbiont communities differ across co-occurring hosts.
- Contingency (spatial proximity): symbiont communities differ across sampling sites and natural gradients (urbanization, elevation).
Approaches:
- Field transect sampling
- Metagenomics
- De novo genome assembly
- Phylogenomics

title: Laboratory for microbial symbiosis, ecology, and evolution
section: Theme II — Diversity at the level of symbiont communities
text:
Theme II — Diversity at the level of symbiont communities
Question: What drives the diversity in symbiosis at the level of symbiont communities?
- Determinism (competition): symbiont communities are highly repeatable across host replicates.
- Contingency (neutrality): symbiont communities differ across replicate hosts.
Approaches:
- Symbiont community enrichment experiments
- Synthetic community construction
- Metagenomics
- Mathematical modeling

title: Laboratory for microbial symbiosis, ecology, and evolution
section: Theme III — Diversity at the level of symbiosis islands
text:
Theme III — Diversity at the level of symbiosis islands
Question: What drives the diversity in symbiosis at the level of mobile symbiosis islands?
- Determinism (selection at gene/genome level): gene sweeps or genome sweeps across symbiont communities.
- Contingency (horizontal gene transfer): fixation of symbiosis islands depends on idiosyncratic HGT events.
Approaches:
- Synthetic community experiments
- Molecular genetics
- Gene editing and tagging
- Computer vision assays
